Dear Ms. Thomas-Cloud:
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
Implementation Sustainability, and Exit Plan (ISEP) requirements, a written corrective
action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also
violations of the ISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from
the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved; this includes identifying
behaviorally specific action steps.
o Repeat violations must include an explanation of why the previous
corrective action plan did not result in compliance.
 Individuals directly responsible for implementing the corrective action step for
each licensing statute and rule, Contract item, DHHS policy or ISEP section
citation; e.g. workers, supervisors, program managers, director, etc.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
implemented and completed.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved; this
includes identifying specific action steps for continuous monitoring.
o MiSACWIS users with access to the Book of Business, InfoView Reports
and the Monthly Child Welfare Management Report should incorporate the
use of these tools as well as other data management reports released by
the Department for continuous monitoring.
 Signature of the responsible party and date.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Claudia Triestram, the area manager at (616) 552-3662.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(4) An agency shall maintain an orientation and training record
for staff members.
One of fourteen new employee files reviewed did not have documentation
(employee signature) that the employee had completed the required orientation.
R 400.12311 Foster parent/agency agreement.
(2) The foster parent/agency agreement shall contain all of the
following provisions:
(e) The role of the lawyer guardian ad litem and the court.
Eight of eight open foster home files reviewed did not have documentation that the
role of the lawyer guardian ad item and the court is provided to the families.
THIS IS A REPEAT VIOLATION FROM THE 2019 RENEWAL INSPECTION WITH
AN APPROVED CAP ON 2/13/2019.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of the
following information: (a) The date the information was received.
One of four special investigations reviewed did not have the Special Evaluation
Report completed within the required fifteen days at the conclusion of the evaluation.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
One of eight open foster care case files reviewed had documentation of a late
Updated Service Plan. This involved one of eighteen Updated Service Plans
reviewed and the report was eight days late.
THIS IS A REPEAT VIOLATION FROM THE 2019 RENEWAL INSPECTION WITH

APPROVED CAP ON 3/19/2018 THE 2017 RENEWAL INSPECION WITH AN

the CAP for this violation can be that the prior CAP will be continued, if the
agency desires.

(1) There shall be a mutually agreed upon contract between the
youth and the agency specifying all of the following: (a) The

DHHS Policy Placement exception request (PER)

A placement exception request (PER) is required for each

One of three open foster care case files requiring a PER for sibling separation

FOM 722-09C Foster Care Action Summary Requirements
Page 1-2
The Foster Care/Juvenile Justice (FC/JJ) Action Summary,
DHHS-69 (RFF 69), is used whenever there is “action” on a
case. The foster care action summary is generated from SWSS
FAJ. The DHHS worker must complete the DHHS-69, Action
Summary (RFF 69) in SWSS. Child placing agencies will
continue to use the DHHS-69, Action Summary template. This
form also serves as notice to the courts of changes in
placements, parent's living situation and the FC worker/agency,
as identifying information is indicated. The FC/JJ action
summary meets licensing requirements for replacement
documentation (See FOM 722-03) and in most cases, agency
transfer and case closing summary (see below). The FC/JJ
action summary must also be used for foster care transfer to
adoption.
Which Cases/When:
All foster care cases where there is:
1. A replacement.
2. Termination from foster care placement.
3. A change in FC worker.
4. Agency change/transfer to another FC agency (if less than 30
days of completion of last case service plan).
5. A change in the parent's living situation.
6. Case closing (if less than 30 days of completion of last case
service plan).
7. Foster care transfer to adoption.
Three of eight open foster care files reviewed did not have the required DHHS-69
Action Summary documented for the placement change. This involved three of
eleven placement changes documented in the files.
Six of eight closed foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation of the
required DHHS-69 Action Summary for the case closing. This involved five missing
Action summaries and an action summary developed on 10/16/19 for a closing that
took place on 8/28/19.
THIS IS A REPEAT VIOLATION FROM THE 2019 RENEWAL INSPECTION WITH
AN APPROVED CAP ON 2/13/2019.

DHHS Policy Required Participation in Development
FOM 722-08C
Page 2
Foster Parent / Caregiver
The individual activities required by the foster parent/caregiver
to meet the specific individual needs of the child placed in their
7

home are included in the PATP. The foster parent/caregiver
must be included in the PATP process. The foster
parent/caregiver signature is required and indicates that the
foster parent/caregiver acknowledges and agrees to the
activities required to meet the needs of the child in their care.
Additionally, the PATP details the services and activities
provided by the foster care worker to assist the foster
parent/caregiver in caring for the child.
Parents and Youth over 14-Years Old
Upon completion of the parent-agency treatment plan and
service agreement, the parent is given a copy for review. Foster
care workers need to ensure the parent understands all areas
within the agreement. Parents and youths age 14 and older
must sign the PATP. If a parent or youth is unavailable or
refuses to sign the PATP, foster care workers must identify, and
document additional action needed to secure the parent’s
and/or youth’s participation in service planning and compliance
with the PATP. As the goals are achieved, modified or
expanded, the updated PATP will reflect this process. Parents
and youths age 14 and older must participate in the
development of each updated treatment plan, allowing for
opportunity to evaluate their progress towards completing goals.
CI 17-096 Treatment Plan Signature Timeframes and
Documentation Requirements
When the treatment plan is completed, signatures for all
appropriate case members must be obtained. Signatures from
all appropriate case members, including youth ages 14 and
older for foster care and youth ages 11 and older for juvenile
justice, should be obtained before the corresponding court
hearing. All treatment plans with a report date of August 1,
2017, or later must have signatures from all appropriate case
members within 30 days of the report date.
Seven of eight open foster care case files reviewed did not have all of the required
signatures on the Parent Agency Treatment Plan as required. This involved no
documentation of four caregivers signatures and three parental signatures. There
was also three PATPs with the caregiver’s signature outside of the required thirty-
day time frame.

AN APPROVED CAP ON 2/13/2019, THE 2018 ANNUAL INSPECTION WITH AN

APPROVED CAP ON 2/17/2017.

DHHS Policy Timely Entry of Caseworker Contacts
FOM 722-06H
page 15-16
All caseworker contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS; this
includes attempted contacts and missed appointments, and all
pertinent information obtained must be summarized and
included in the appropriate section of the case service plan.
All face-to-face contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS, within
five business days of the contact.
Five of eight open foster care case files reviewed did not have a timely entry of
caseworker contacts for each contact entered. This involved thirty seven of seventy-
one contacts that were timely. This is a 52% compliance rate.

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas
 The agency was using an outdated foster parent/agency agreement form.
The agency agreed that they need to update their forms to reflect
appropriate information.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
 The agency did not seek any consultation at this time.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
The agency has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The first investigation requiring a corrective action plan involved allegations of the
agency’s assessment of a specific home and the timeliness in assessing a
household member. A complete investigation resulted in a finding that the agency
did not complete and submit a timely CAP related to the clearance and assessment
10

of a household member. Additional findings were discovered and involved a special
evaluation exceeding 90-days without approval from the Chief Administrator or
designee. There was also no documentation to justify the delay in the report being
completed. The agency submitted a CAP that involved the worker establishing a
licensing violation rather than a safety plan and the supervisor not approving a
safety plan if a CAP is more appropriate. The CAP for the second violation involves
the caseworker being trained on the timeline of a Special Evaluation and the
supervisor developing a tracking system for Special Evaluations.
The second corrective action plan involved the agency’s 2019 renewal licensing
inspection.
Safety Alerts:
There were three safety alerts documented during the visit by the Analyst
Alert #1
Concerns: The licensed home was using portable electric heaters in the bedrooms
at the time of the visit. The licensed home had an electrical outlet that did not have a
cover on it at the time of the visit. This was the light switch at the end of the hallway
where the bedrooms are located.
Resolution: The agency provided documentation that the caseworker addressed
these issues with the family and the necessary changes were made. The agency
documented that the family understood that they are not to use the portable heater
and that they agreed to remove the portable heater. The agency also provided a
picture of the electrical outlet with a cover as required.
Alert #2
Concerns: The relative home was using a portable electric heater in the master
bedroom at the time of the visit. The relative home currently has all of the boys in
one-bedroom upstairs (which does not appear to be big enough for all children) as
they are doing construction and painting on the other room. The relative stated that
they did not discuss a timeline for completion of the work with the agency.
Resolution: The agency provided documentation that the issues have been
resolved. They reported that the family “removed the heater immediately” and
“understand that they cannot use a portable heater”. Documentation provided
indicates that a safety plan was developed and signed by the foster parent. They
provided documentation that the family followed through with the ceiling being
repaired and painted within the required 14-days outlined in the safety plan.
Alert #3
11

Concerns: The relative stated that their carbon monoxide detector does not work,
and that they do not currently have working smoke detectors. The electricity is not
currently working in parts of the master bedroom, master bathroom, and the laundry
room. The foster children's bedroom, the adoptive children's bedroom, and the living
room all have broken windows. The relative stated that the agency was helping them
with the windows but were unsure when this would be completed. The relative
indicated that the roof on the home was recently leaking, and that they were unsure
if it was still leaking. There are observable water spots on several parts of the ceiling
in the home.
Resolution: The agency provided documentation that the identified issues were
investigated and resolved. The agency completed a face-to-face inspection on
2/7/2020 and obtained pictures of the damage to the ceiling and windows. They also
determined that there is electricity in the master bedroom, master bathroom and
laundry room. They documented that not all of the outlets were working at this time.
It is also documented that the caregiver agreed not to allow the children in the three
areas (master bedroom, master bathroom and laundry room). They indicated that
the children are not normally in these areas of the house. The agency scheduled to
have the windows inspected and measured for repairs on 2/11/2020. This is
documented as having occurred and the agency provided documentation of the
installation having been completed on all three windows by 3/2/2020. There is
documentation that the installation was delayed due to weather issues. In regard to
the fire detector and carbon monoxide detector, the agency provided documentation
that these were installed in December 2019. The agency documented that at the
time of this report, the electrician is scheduled to begin working on repairing all of the
identified electrical issues, which should occur the week of 3/16/2020. In regard to
the roof issues, the agency documented that the caregiver is in the process of
obtaining quotes for a grant to have the roof repaired. They also provided
documentation that the roof is not actively leaking at this time but does need repair.
There is documentation that the agency is scheduled to have a meeting with the
caregiver on 3/9/2020 to get an update on the roof repair schedule.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
